title: runtime/Client state machine broken after upgrade to socket.io@4
body:
We just upgraded to `socket.io@4`. For some reason, `disconnect` and `init_ack` behavior is not as before. It sometimes connects multiple times in rapid succession, and then sends data before `init_ack` was received.

It's probably a race condition where the second client instant receives the first instance's `init_ack` somehow.

* [x] Investigate why
* [x] Fix it.

title: Optimize Call Graph to deal with 50+k nodes per root

labels.name: performance
labels.description: Performance of runtime analysis tools can be quite a nuisance.

body:
* [ ] Things get too slow when a call graph root has many descendants. Test this with Chart.js#2. There are 40+k descendants in some of the roots.
  * Make sure to use the right settings so that things don't slow down to a grinding halt:
    * Run without debugging ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/282899/111025465-4a47bc80-841f-11eb-84ed-526f76aeba7e.png)
    * in `dbux-runtime\src\RuntimeMonitor.js` set `tracesDisabled` from `0` to `1`
  * [x] When working with such a root or its children, things get extremely slow. Find a way to fix this.
* [x] Do some preliminary performance profiling
  * Turns out, it can render the graph roots real quick (about 1 second).
  * After the first second, it will asynchronously keep adding everything else for some 10-20 seconds (16s in my case). While doing that, the Graph view is interactive, but too laggy to use.
  * Summary: Total time spent running our code = 11.1s
    ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/282899/110964668-63545d00-838e-11eb-92e5-963453235b8f.png)
  * Flamegraph (while building graph initially; after a Graph view restart):
    ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/282899/110962576-15d6f080-838c-11eb-80e4-42ddf9a1e733.png)
  * Tasks: This indicates, that the rasterizer thread is probably a bottleneck. (because we are adding that many nodes to HTML)
    ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/282899/110963402-fd1b0a80-838c-11eb-8c65-e1ba28cc7eb0.png)
  * Scripting breakdown (Total Time)
    ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/282899/110963847-8599ab00-838d-11eb-9b91-23eaff509c9b.png)
  * Scripting breakdown (Self Time)
    ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/282899/110964034-b5e14980-838d-11eb-949c-89b3a06f9f01.png)
  * Confirmed: HTML rendering takes a lot of time (half of the total time spent (11.1s))
    ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/282899/110965866-9d722e80-838f-11eb-96e2-8fc9b84e93b6.png)

* Maybe clear up some inconsistencies in above analysis result:
  * [ ] Why does `compileHtmlElement` have three very different numbers?
    * `Self Time = 2.7s`, `Total Time = 4.2s` and the time spent inside it's `template.html = html` line is `5.8s`
    * Maybe I made a mistake recording it? Maybe we should start by repeating the analysis one more time to confirm.




## Improve performance

* [x] Lazy load for all nodes.

* Other possible ideas:
  * New "omission node" feature:
    * If a context of same `staticContextId` has already been rendered within the same root (let's call them "repeated contexts"), add an omission node instead.
    * For any other "repeated context" that is either (i) a child of, or (ii) is following (on the timeline) an "omission node" : merge into the omission node.
  * We might have to lazy-load all layers, not just the root layer... ?
  * Maybe reducing `components`/`controllers` can help a little bit (but probably not much)

title: [dbux-cli] `esnext` configuration bug: requires (sometimes) non-existing babel plugins
body:
# Bug Description

`dbux-cli` (and thus also `dbux-code`'s `runCommands`) can only work if Babel plugins are available using the standard Node `require` algorithm (i.e. it must be in some `node_modules` folder, relative to the program entry point). Explanation:

* If `esnext` is enabled, `dbux-cli\src\util\buildBabelOptions.js` uses `config\babel-presets-node.js` which in turn requires several babel plugins.
* Sadly, Babel uses a custom `require` mechanism, which prevents us from aliasing those plugins (like we can alias all other libraries, including Dbux's own libraries)

# Workarounds

* Either: If the syntax of the program is fully supported by Node: set `--esnext=false` in your `dbux.${runMode}.dbuxArgs` settings (it is `true` by default via `dbux-code/package.json`)
* Or: install all plugins manually, in the folder where the file is, or any of its ancestors.
  * `npm install -D @babel/plugin-proposal-class-properties @babel/plugin-proposal-optional-chaining @babel/plugin-proposal-decorators @babel/plugin-proposal-function-bind @babel/plugin-syntax-export-default-from @babel/plugin-syntax-dynamic-import @babel/plugin-transform-runtime`
  * or: `yarn add --dev @babel/plugin-proposal-class-properties @babel/plugin-proposal-optional-chaining @babel/plugin-proposal-decorators @babel/plugin-proposal-function-bind @babel/plugin-syntax-export-default-from @babel/plugin-syntax-dynamic-import @babel/plugin-transform-runtime`

# Fix the bug


* First: Just try to require the actual plugin, instead of passing the plugin name to Babel in `config\babel-presets-node.js`.
* If that does not work: Not sure yet. Probably automatically detect the problem, and offer present above solution(s) to the user by pro-actively.

title: [Call Graph] in `ContextNode`: split `nodeToggleBtn` into two

labels.name: performance
labels.description: Performance of runtime analysis tools can be quite a nuisance.

body:
Goal: don't accidentally expand the entire sub-tree (since that can be bad for performance) if you only want to toggle between showing and not showing children. For that, we want to offer another button, so we are not forced to toggle through all modes.

title: Projects: todomvc is thrown into "detached head mode", and file changes are ignored
body:
In todomvc we use the new relatively new `switchToBugPatchTag` function which is buggy: It causes all changes after the first install to be ignored.

* [x] Find a way to update the tag (or otherwise checkout "the latest version"), instead of always rolling back to the originally installed version.
* [x] Make sure, user changes are not discarded
* [x] Make sure, changes to asset files are also accounted for (at least in dev mode).
  * We attempt (and fail to) do this in `BugRunner.activateBug` by calling `project.installAssets()`
* [ ] Make sure, the local branch is not thrown into detached head mode. Sounds like it might cause more trouble further down the line?


## Steps to reproduce:

1. Run `todomvc`'s error1
2. Make a random change to `dbux-projects/assets/todomvc-es6/dbux.webpack.config.js`
3. Restart error (make sure, webpack also restarts)
4. Observe bug: `dbux_projects/todovmc-es6/dbux.webpack.config.js` does not have the change.
5. Manually remove `dbux_projects/todovmc-es6/dbux.webpack.config.js`
6. Observe bug: Webpack config content is still rolled back to the **original version**

## Possible fix

*  On auto commit, delete and re-add tag?

## More

There are a few weird log entries, hinting at overwritten patches that were never committed:

> [DBUX Project todomvc-es6]  Warning: you are leaving 1 commit behind, not connected to
> any of your branches:

> to do so with:
> 
>  git branch <new-branch-name> bb5fe74
> 
> HEAD is now at 6fe4eb9 [dbux auto commit] Patch error1

and:

> [DBUX Project todomvc-es6] auto commit
> [DBUX Project todomvc-es6]  [detached HEAD cf86a78] [dbux auto commit]

title: When code schedules two callbacks to execute in the same tick, Dbux cannot correctly resolve their stacks
Discussion: First version of Async Call Graph

labels.name: discussion
labels.description: WARNING: **This issue is only to collect well-thought-out and researched commentary.** If you want t

body:
## Visualize Async Call Graph
* [ ] Assign correct `threadId` to each `context` (first manually according to our established rules; will ultimatley be done by instrumentation)
* [ ] `vertex-edge` visualization: Each vertex in a thread's column represents a run that has at least one `context` participating in that thread. 
  * [ ] Vertical edges of that graph represent a logical call chain on the same thread
  * [ ] Horizontal "arc" edges represent a "fork"
  * [ ] next to the "root" of each thread, add a small "upward arrow" button that takes you to the node that "forked" this node, if the "forker" is not on the same level (e.g. a run that observed multiple parallel `setTimeout` or other callback scheduling events)
* [ ] Add a mode to toggle: (i) add"new threads" to the right, (ii) add "new threads" to the left (and shove existing threads to the right)
* [ ] Add a mode to toggle between (i) vertex-edge and (ii) original call sub graph visualizations
* [ ] Files' initializations should be in same thread

## Instrumentation

TODO



## Old Notes

The `AsyncCallEdgeCollection` has the purpose of representing asynchronous edges along the dynamic Call Graph.

It is mostly a tree but with some nodes potentially having multiple parents (but we don't have to worry about multiple parents initially).

* Each node is some type of `ExecutionContext`
* The collection contains all edges between two asynchronous nodes: parent `p` and child `c` indicates that `c` follows `p`

For that, we ultimately need instrumentation to add an edge during the following events:

* [ ] first context of any (synchronous) "run"
* [ ] promise chain (`then`, `catch`, `finally`, `Promise.all` etc.)
* [ ] when `await` is resolved, add an edge between the two contexts, one before and one after the `await`

## Unresolved issues

* [ ] detect and visualize a fork with only a single asynchronous offspring
* [ ] when callbacks get scheduled, we also need to establish a link.
  * [ ] Maybe, if they get passed as arguments, always add a link?
* [ ] generator functions
  * NOTE: Generator functions are generally "thread-agnostic". Executing (parts of) a generator function does not necessarily logically tie future executions of that function to that thread.

body:
Goal: An improved and dynamic runtime version of "Find all References".

@edisonhello:
* [ ] instrument (in `functionVisitor`), trace the function declaration.
* [ ] take a look at `__samplesInput__/functions1.js`
  * NOTE: There are five node types that alias `Function` (see https://babeljs.io/docs/en/babel-types). Some are expressions, some are not.
  * Since we want to trace all of them, we need to convert all functions to expressions.
* [ ] Convert any `Function` to an expression (you can see some examples in `functions1.js`)
* [ ] Trace the function value (just like in Object trace; consider simply using `wrapExpression` here?)

* future work: Also make this work with `bind`, `curry`, etc.?

@MiccWan:
* [ ] add a filter or "mode" button to `Object Traces` node:
  * [ ] `all traces` - same functionality as before; just list all traces
  * [ ] `all code sites` - list all `staticTraces` (NOTE: static traces are "code sites") of all object traces that reference any of the traces of the same `staticTraceId`
    * NOTE: this way, it will not list the same static trace multiple times, even if (i) the object is used in the loop, or (ii) the current trace has multiple executions itself.
    * NOTE2: If we use this on a function object, it is similar to (but much more precise than) "Find All References"
    * NOTE3: This way, (unlike traditional "Find All References") it is limited to finding only static traces involving instances that were traced in the line of code; not of the variable declaration.

body:
We had this bug:

* [x] When closing or cancelling Terminal command, dbux-practice stays "currently busy" forever

Steps to reproduce:

* Run a dbux-practice bug
* Cancel in terminal (e.g. CTRL+C)
* -> Try doing anything -> Always "currently busy"

That happened because the code has a big problem:

* There were multiple `window.onDidCloseTerminal` handlers that acted in conflict with one another.

Also, the entire code looks like someone started working on it, then someone else worked on it, and there was no communication on how things should work (😄 ）. There are several more issues:

* `dispose` does not get called consistently
* `watcher` is somehow only a local variable, not a field. Thus `dispose` does not take care of it.
* There are probably more problems leading to more inconsistencies and bugs.......

When testing, especially the first bug (always "currently busy") should have been very obvious. Maybe we can review how to test things :)

title: New concept in dbux-data: `codeChunk`

milestone.description:

body:
* [ ] New concept in dbux-data: `codeChunk`
  * A new high-level concept that is smaller than a `context` but not as small as a `trace`.
  * We split a context into mutiple chunks based along all `CallExpressions` that has recorded child traces
  * A `codeChunk` is the loc from `start = ContextStart | TraceOfAnyCallExpressionWithChildren` to right before the next `codeChunk` or the end of the context
  * [Code chunk explanation](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/15LTc_V6GaojyZcP-rOC_LBvS-EVKycgm9vW7GjCaTT0/edit#slide=id.ga0ccf9fa7d_0_9)
* [ ] Anywhere where we record `function` (`context`) information, also record `codeChunk` information
* [ ] add utility functions to get all kinds of information (such as `loc`, `traces`) etc. by `codeChunk`
* [ ] in Pathways, count steps by `codeChunk`s touched.
  * [ ] exclude a `codeChunk` if only it's first or last trace was touched?

title: Improve trace value information: distinguish between expression + statement

labels.name: instrumentation
labels.description: Related to how we instrument the code in `dbux-babel-plugin`

body:
Goal: For many intents and purposes of analysis, granularity of "trace" is too small, we might want to count against individual "lines of code, that is all non-block statements.

Examples:

* `f(g())` -> `f(g())`
* `if (!a && !b) { c; d; } ` -> `!a && !b`, `c`, `d` (total of 3 different non-block statements)
* `c = d * 3` -> `c = d * 3`

* [ ] add new `TraceCategory` enum with 2 values: `{ Expression, Statement }`
* [ ] upon instrumentation, add `category = TraceCategory...` to all `staticTrace`s
* [ ] add new index to `RuntimeDataProvider` on `staticTraces`: `byCategory`
* [ ] in `RuntimeDataProvider` -> `StaticTraceCollection`  add post processing:
  * for each `staticTrace`, determine it's `statementTraceId`
  * NOTE: This might require more AST information, so as to keep track of the parent-child relationship
* [ ] in `dataProviderUtil` add utility functions `/** @return {Trace} */ getStatementTrace(dp, traceId)` and `/** @return {StaticTrace} */ getStaticStatementTrace(dp, staticTraceId)`

body:
Db usage costs money: Whenever we read or write the DB, it counts toward a quota. Once a certain monthly threshold is exceeded, it will shut down or start draining money. We want to make sure that reads + writes are reasonable, and be able to track down unreasonable amounts.

* [x] store `dbPerformanceCounters` object in memento and keep updating it
* [x] whenever we read or write, add one to corresponding performance counter
  * [x] dbPerformanceCounters[collectionName].{nReads,nWrites}
  * [x] dbPerformanceCounters[collectionName][currentTime % 30min].{nReads,nWrites} // read + write histogram in N minute buckets
* [x] if a 30min bucket exceeds some threshold (let's say 300) of `nReads` or `nWrites`: logError(`Warning: excessive database access detected`)
* add commands:
  * [x] show DB stats
  * [x] clear DB stats

title: Selective Tracing

labels.name: performance
labels.description: Performance of runtime analysis tools can be quite a nuisance.

body:
When using Dbux on big projects, things get a bit slow. E.g. with eslint (200k+ loc), the call graph in first test has around 4000 nodes.

Also, in general, omniscient debuggers suffer from scalability issues, because of the sheer amount of data they have to work with, making performance analysis a crucial part of the research, as well as the UX in general.


* [ ] Identify some of the main bottlenecks and add code that tracks performance of the bottlenecks
* [ ] Improve/simplify some of the features to better handle the amount of data


## New Feature: Selective tracing

* [ ] allow only tracing contexts, no traces, and speed that up (`TracesDisabled`)
  * [ ] missing `ContextEndTrace` leads to many (incorrect) error flags
  * [ ] currently `TracesDisabled` is about 2x slower than "Run without Dbux" -> can we improve that further? -> need to profile.
* [ ] analyze (and if necessary improve) runtime data sending (use separate Worker?)
* [ ] selective function + object tracing
  * -> basically https://github.com/Domiii/dbux/issues/219

Other things worth improving:

* [ ] when installing in `dbux-practice`, make sure, it won't run `prepublish` (reduces install time)

title: [traceDetailsView] Grouping for `nearby values`

milestone.title: Alpha Launch (Workshop-ready)
milestone.description:
Allow anyone to easily work through existing "sample bugs", use Dbux to assist the bug finding, and keep progress of solved bugs.

* Dbux-practice workflow with Express (first ten bugs) works flawlessly
* Eslint bugs can also be worked on
* Basic version of debugging pathways
* Everything can be done online.

body:
Currently, all values are entirely ungrouped. Instead, we want to have two levels:

* [x] On the first level, show all "outer-most" traces of current `context`
* [x] If a trace has nested traces: list all nested traces as children
* [x] make sure that the node that contains the `selectedTrace` is expanded

NOTE: Maybe we can re-use and refine the algorithm we use when clicking the "select trace" button repeatedly to determine this sort of (simplistic) "trace tree".

## Example

This code

```js
if (f(x)) {
  g(h(y, z), w);
}
return null;
```

should result in the following (two-level) tree (given that `f(x)` returns a [truthy value](https://developer.mozilla.org/en/docs/Glossary/Truthy#:~:text=In%20JavaScript%2C%20a%20truthy%20value,%2C%20undefined%20%2C%20and%20NaN%20).)):

* `f(x)`
  * `f`
  * `x`
* `g(h(y, z), w);`
  * `g`
  * `h`
  * `y`
  * `z`
  * `h(y, z)`
  * `w`

title: Build dbux-practice backend

milestone.title: Alpha Launch (Workshop-ready)
milestone.description:
Allow anyone to easily work through existing "sample bugs", use Dbux to assist the bug finding, and keep progress of solved bugs.

* Dbux-practice workflow with Express (first ten bugs) works flawlessly
* Eslint bugs can also be worked on
* Basic version of debugging pathways
* Everything can be done online.

body:
## auth

* [x] create dbux-server project w/ express
* [x] add `.env` file and `yarn add dotenv`
   * [x] add `dotenv` to server's `index.js`
   * [x] write `GOOGLE_APPLICATION_CREDENTIALS=.secret/service-account.json` to `.env` file
   * [x] copy service-account file to `.secret/service-account.json`
   * [x] add `.secret` to `.gitignore` (if not in there already)
* server
   * [x] add a new route `login` to create a custom token using the admin sdk
   * [x] copy and use the `fetchGithubAccountData` function to verify the `accessToken`
   * [x] if verified, generate custom token https://firebase.google.com/docs/auth/admin/create-custom-tokens
   * [x] else, send 400
* client: create and use new `BackendAuth2.js` (keep the old one in case we can fix the old issue)
   * add new `login()` function:
      * [x] try to login using previously stored `customToken` (memento)
      * if not logged in:
         * [x] use `interactiveGithubLogin` to get Github `accessToken`
         * [x] send that `accessToken` to server and get `customToken` back
         * [x] use customToken to login: https://firebase.google.com/docs/auth/web/custom-auth

## stores

* Stores ("Store" is synonymous with "Model") are the interfaces that allow us to read and write remote database data
* All stores inherit from `FirestoreStore`.
* `Db` should make sure that data will be written, even if user is offline.
   * NOTE: This is mostly done in `db2.js`
   * [x] blocked by Domi: need to fix `FirestoreContainer` first
   * In order to keep things simple, all writes only use `firestore.set(id, data, {merge : true})` on the lowest level (implemented in `Db`'s write methods).
   * [x] If offline, any writes need to be stored locally (via externals -> memento)
   * [x] When going online again, cached store changes need to be flushed to remote (and then removed locally)
      * the two steps of (1) flush -> (2) remove from cache must be "as atomic as possible" to avoid duplications or data loss

> The terminal process "C:\Program Files\Git\usr\bin\bash.exe '-c', 'node c:/Users/Domi/.vscode/extensions/domi.dbux-code-0.1.27/resources/_dbux_run.js ; sleep 100000'" terminated with exit code: 512.

Biggest problem: This even happens when using CTRL+C after the program has alread finished running.

First do some research:

* [x] Behavior on Windows: exit code 512
* [x] Behavior on Linux: ?
* [x] Behavior on Mac: ?

Solve:

* [x] After finishing, and before starting to sleep: `echo 'Done. You can close the Terminal now.'`. Or even better, can we time the entire run?
* [x] Exit code 512 is a Windows-only problem.
   * Maybe related to disrupting `sleep` or trying to sleep after CTRL+C was sent?

* [x] If program has already exited and we have a result, don't flash an error message.
* [x] In general, make sure that `reject` or `resolve` (either of) are only ever called once. If either of the two is called, don't call any of the two anymore.  In that case, if another error occurs, use `warn` to log the error.

body:
* Order of trace selection only breaks in more complicated settings.
* NOTE: This works correctly in `calc1.js`

However, in `fibonacci.js`:

## Steps to reproduce

* select the `n - 2` trace (good)
* select again

## Expected

When pressing select repeatedly I would want to see the following order of selected traces:
* `n - 2`
* `fibonacci(n - 2)`
* `fibonacci(n - 1) + fibonacci(n - 2)`
* `n <= 2 ? 1 : fibonacci(n - 1) + fibonacci(n - 2)`

## Actual

* `n - 2`
* `n <= 2 ? 1 : fibonacci(n - 1) + fibonacci(n - 2)`
* other...

## Solution

* This is probably due to the recursion.
* Can probably be solved by simply limiting repeated trace selection to *current context*. (Don't allow trace selection to jump between contexts?)

title: Make runtime value collection configuration configurable via @dbux/babel-plugin

labels.name: discussion
labels.description: WARNING: **This issue is only to collect well-thought-out and researched commentary.** If you want t

labels.name: performance
labels.description: Performance of runtime analysis tools can be quite a nuisance.

body:
In order to render the value of variables and make them available for analysis, we need to actually copy all touched variables while the program executes.

* That can get very slow very fast, especially if you operate on large arrays, objects and strings. 
* That is why we have a few parameters to tune.
* Currently, those parameters are hardcoded  `SerializationConfig` in [valueCollection](dbux-runtime/src/data/valueCollection.js) and cannot be configured from the outside.

In order to make it configurable, we need to add new `dbuxRuntime` property to `@dbux/babel-plugin`'s configuration set:

* [ ] Provide parameters to `@dbux/babel-plugin` from `@dbux/cli` in some form of command parameters, as defined in `commandCommon.js`
* [ ] In [@dbux/babel-plugin](dbux-babel-plugin)'s `initDbux` take `dbuxRuntime` config from `state.opts` (just like `filenameOverride`)  and provide to `initProgram` in `staticData.js`.
* [ ] In `@dbux/runtime`'s `initProgram`, take that data and store it in `this.config` (which exposes it globally as `__dbux__.config`)
* [ ] Instead of hardcoding `SerializationConfig` in [valueCollection](dbux-runtime/src/data/valueCollection.js), get the config options from `__dbux__.config`
   * [ ] Use lodash's `defaultsDeep` to make sure all values have a default value.

title: Async Call Graph

labels.name: discussion
labels.description: WARNING: **This issue is only to collect well-thought-out and researched commentary.** If you want t

body:
Milestone: https://github.com/Domiii/dbux/milestone/2

Currently, we only support a "synchronous call graph", meaning that **all** execution is organized in a single serial thread. While that makes sense (especially since JavaScript is inherently single-threaded), logically we want to group "threads of asynchronous contexts" together.

That means that, for now, invocation of promise callbacks (callbacks passed to `then()`, `catch()`, `finally()` etc.), and even resuming of an `async` function will result in a new `run`, seen executing serially in the Call Graph, and you cannot easily trace a single promise or the execution of a asingle `async` function. Instead, they will be cut up into multiple pieces scattered across the linear Call Graph representation, and sprinkled with other unrelated calls that happen to occur in between.

What we want here instead is an "asynchronous call graph" representation, organized around  (and visually presenting) "asynchronous threads" running in parallel.

This feature is absolutely necessary for proper understanding modern, asynchronous JavaScript, and yet we don't have it yet. Maybe we can make this happen soon enough :)

title: Discuss preventing Heisenbugs from property accessors with side effects

labels.name: discussion
labels.description: WARNING: **This issue is only to collect well-thought-out and researched commentary.** If you want t

body:
As mentioned in the README, Heisenbugs can occur when Dbux tries to gather values from properties with [side effects](https://softwareengineering.stackexchange.com/questions/40297/what-is-a-side-effect). We want to avoid that.

WARNING: **This issue is only to collect well-thought-out and researched commentary.** If you want to **discuss** or **ask questions**, please bring them to the [Dbux Discord](https://discord.gg/bdD3yH).

Just like [ESLint configuration comments](https://eslint.org/docs/user-guide/configuring#using-configuration-comments) (`// eslint-disable` etc), Dbux should allow developers to turn off gathering data from specifically marked properties, or disable tracing on specific lines of code using directive comments.

labels.description: WARNING: **This issue is only to collect well-thought-out and researched commentary.** If you want t

body:
This issue is to allow for collecting initial feedback regarding more complex data analysis methods and tools to be used on Dbux data. 

WARNING: **This issue is only to collect well-thought-out and researched commentary.** If you want to **discuss** or **ask questions**, please bring them to the [Dbux Discord](https://discord.gg/bdD3yH).

As a general hint, you probably want to get started with this task by looking at our two data-related folders:

1. [@dbux/data](dbux-data) is the JavaScript module we also use internally to preprocess and manage all the data before visualizing it and making it interactive in the [Dbux VSCode Plugin](dbux-code).
1. [analysis](analysis) contains a few Python notebooks for rudimentary analysis on extracted data for testing and development purposes. We exported the data via the (also rather crude) [dbux.exportApplicationData command](dbux-code/src/codeUtil/codeExport.js)

body:
One great value of the traditional debugger is to see the value of variables in context in one table. Useful feature to have.

Dbux currently does not quite comprehend "variables", as we deal in traces and have not analyzed the role of individual variables yet - but at least we can show expression values of nearby expressions?

For now, we can:

1. Add new "Nearby Traces" node to traceDetailsView
1. One node per contexts on the current callstack just like the traditional debugger does it with scopes.
1. One node per staticTrace (that are expressions) of that context
1. Value of the actual trace that got executed in that context, closest to `selectedTrace`
1. Visualize with `node's label` = `staticTrace label` and `node's description` = `traceValueLabel`

The screenshot shows how VSCode is now grouping by block, but I think that just makes things more confusing.

We can just group by context, makes things more intuitive to my mind. (I think that is how they used to do it, too.)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/282899/89891546-d97dbf00-dc07-11ea-9d28-da77cec5295a.png)


Thoughts?

- [x] Report results of all tools back in the form of a `codeModal` (one line per tool)

## Basic Tools
Check if all dependent OS tools are available:

* which or where.exe
* bash (all shell execution must work)
* node v12+
* pm
* git


## System independence
* [x] On Cygwin, `which` returns a unix-style path, which needs further lookup via `cygpath -w`.
   * On Windows: Use `where` instead of `which`
   * For that, implement all functions in `dbux-projects\src\util\which.js`
* Use `which()` from `which.js` instead of `Process.execCapture...(which...)`
   * [x] in checkSystem.js
   * [x] in terminalUtil.js

body:
We currently call `graphRoot.refresh` on `allApplications.selection.onApplicationsChanged` in `GraphDocument`. However that causes race conditions when refreshing too fast because client-side nodes might get disposed while we are still adding them asynchronously. We want to prevent that.

Also, `allApplications.addApplication` might remove an old and add a new application in one go, thereby emiting `applicationsChanged` refreshing twice. It should tell the `remove` method not to emit the event instead (maybe add a `silent` parameter).

title: Add support for Actor Model

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

body:
## Explanation

Variants of the [Actor Model](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Actor_model) (often in form of the [Entity Component System (or "Paradigm")](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Entity_component_system) (ECS)) is commonly used in game development.

The Actor Model centers around agents, which themselves are objects, and also "individual threads of execution". Agent state can only be modified by the agent itself by calling methods on each agent. Execution of methods is atomic in regard to the agent's own state, no two different methods can be running at the same time.

The ECS (commonly seen in games, and arguably made most popular through the Unity (and other) game engine(s)) shares the idea of agents (also called "Entities" or "GameObjects") managing their own state, but with less constraints and assurances (especially: no atomicity or isolated state!). However, viewing Entities (or GameObjects) in ECS game engines as "Actors" in the Actor Model might largely aid us in debugging their run-time.


## Checkpoints

* [ ] Add a game project for testing to `dbux-projects`
   * [ ] https://github.com/tobspr/shapez.io
* [ ] Add `FlowMode.AgentModel` with only selected set of agents (i.e. those agents/entities/objects we want to investigate) as the parameter

### [important] v0.1

When in that mode...
* [ ] display all object executions of selected (entities) in horizontally parallel threads (similar to [FlowMode.Async](https://github.com/Domiii/dbux/issues/128))`)
* [ ] Only instrument/track calls/access of selected objects?
   * Q: Is this possible without significant reduction in FPS?

### [nice-to-have] v0.2: Global System View
* [ ] Add `FlowMode.AgentModel` without parameter -> Track *all* object executions?
* [ ] Problem: At each update step, we might have hundreds, thousands or even more parallelly executing agents. Need to simplify/cull/group.
* [ ] group execution of object methods by the objects that they belong to (i.e. `this
* TODO: more
